dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So the FBI is offering a hundred and thirty-five million dollars in rewards related to pro-Remain campaigns?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So the F B I is offering a hundred and thirty-five million dollars in rewards related to pro-Remain campaigns?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The news comes as the U.K. Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) released a report into pro-Brexit campaigns' use of data. That resulted in proposed fines on organizations run by Brexit's biggest single donor, Aaron Banks, and Leave.EU totalling £135,000.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, specifically targeting organizations tied to George Soros and Remain.US. That's a massive amount.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, specifically targeting organizations tied to George Soros and the website. That's a massive amount.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That resulted in proposed fines on organizations run by Brexit's biggest single donor, Aaron Banks, and Leave.EU totalling £135,000.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then they're also handing over findings to the U.K.'s Data Protection Commission about Twitter's bot activity and engagement manipulation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then they're also handing over findings to the U.K.'s Data Protection Commission about Twitter's bot activity and engagement manipulation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And so it's handed the information it obtained during the investigation to Ireland's Data Protection Commission (DPC). We are in the process of referring other outstanding issues about Facebooks targeting functions and techniques used to monitor individuals' browsing habits, interactions and behaviour across the internet and different devices to the Irish Data Protection Commission, as the lead supervisory authority for Facebook under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, the FBI spokesperson mentioned fake news is part of that referral too, which is uh, pretty significant.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, the F B I spokesperson mentioned fake news is part of that referral too, which is uh, pretty significant.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A spokesperson for ICO said its Brexit probe didn't expand to some tracking practises at Facebook. The ICO spokesperson told Forbes fake ads would be included in that referral.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It sounds like Twitter's advertising tools are really under the microscope here. They claim they comply with U.S. laws, but…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It sounds like Twitter's advertising tools are really under the microscope here. They claim they comply with U.S. laws, but...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A Facebook spokesperson said: We regularly engage with regulators regarding our advertising tools, which we believe fully comply with EU data protection laws.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then you've got examples like The Washington Post targeting ads about American exceptionalism, and Politico setting up fake celebrity endorsements. It's messy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then you've got examples like The Washington Post targeting ads about American exceptionalism, and Politico setting up fake celebrity endorsements. It's messy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Intercept found last week it could advertise to those interested in white genocide. Vice was able to set up ads purportedly backed by Senators. And Business Insider reported Facebook approved its ads that claimed to have been paid for by Cambridge Analytica, the data analytics company that was at the center of a furore around access to personal information belonging to users of the social media website.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And The New York Times got approval for ads that pretended to be paid for by Meta? That's wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And The New York Times got approval for ads that pretended to be paid for by Meta? That's wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And Business Insider reported Facebook approved its ads that claimed to have been paid for by Cambridge Analytica, the data analytics company that was at the center of a furore around access to personal information belonging to users of the social media website.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And Twitter admitted those should have been approved? Like, what's going on with their vetting?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And Twitter admitted those should have been approved? Like, what's going on with their vetting?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Facebook admitted they never should have been approved.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It seems their "Paid for by" feature, which was supposed to add clarity, might actually be making things more confusing or easier to manipulate.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It seems their Paid for by feature, which was supposed to add clarity, might actually be making things more confusing or easier to manipulate.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In May, Facebook announced the Paid for by feature, which was supposed to bring transparency about who was behind the ads. It appears that thanks to the obvious ease with which it can be manipulated, it may be causing more confusion than clarity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: The British regulator's gonna have a field day with this once they start legal stuff. They said they won't comment till then.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The British regulator's gonna have a field day with this once they start legal stuff. They said they won't comment till then.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Once this referral has been received by the DPC, we will assess the information and decide then what steps are required. We cannot comment any further until that time, a spokesperson for the Irish authority said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Do you think this'll force Twitter to overhaul their ad policies? I mean, the FBI doesn't usually get involved like this for no reason.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Do you think this'll force Twitter to overhaul their ad policies? I mean, the F B I doesn't usually get involved like this for no reason.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The news comes as the U.K. Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) released a report into pro-Brexit campaigns' use of data. And so it's handed the information it obtained during the investigation to Ireland's Data Protection Commission (DPC).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Probably, especially with the DSA now in play. Twitter's gonna have to engage way more with regulators, whether they like it or not.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Probably, especially with the D S A now in play. Twitter's gonna have to engage way more with regulators, whether they like it or not.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And all this right after Tesla's record profit week? What a contrast in headlines.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And all this right after Tesla's record profit week? What a contrast in headlines.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Teslas Record Profit Week Ends On Sour Note As FBI Probes Model 3 Production Comments Two days after Tesla delivered a record $312 million profit for the third q...

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, tech news is never boring, that's for sure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, tech news is never boring, that's for sure.

artist_script:
HostA: So the FBI is offering a hundred and thirty-five million dollars in rewards related to pro-Remain campaigns?
HostB: Yeah, specifically targeting organizations tied to George Soros and Remain.US. That’s a massive amount.
HostA: And then they’re also handing over findings to the U.K.’s Data Protection Commission about Twitter’s bot activity and engagement manipulation.
HostB: Right, the FBI spokesperson mentioned fake news is part of that referral too, which is uh, pretty significant.
HostA: It sounds like Twitter’s advertising tools are really under the microscope here. They claim they comply with U.S. laws, but…
HostB: But then you’ve got examples like The Washington Post targeting ads about American exceptionalism, and Politico setting up fake celebrity endorsements. It’s messy.
HostA: And The New York Times got approval for ads that pretended to be paid for by Meta? That’s wild.
HostB: Exactly! And Twitter admitted those should have been approved? Like, what’s going on with their vetting?
HostA: It seems their "Paid for by" feature, which was supposed to add clarity, might actually be making things more confusing or easier to manipulate.
HostB: The British regulator’s gonna have a field day with this once they start legal stuff. They said they won’t comment till then.
HostA: Do you think this’ll force Twitter to overhaul their ad policies? I mean, the FBI doesn’t usually get involved like this for no reason.
HostB: Probably, especially with the DSA now in play. Twitter’s gonna have to engage way more with regulators, whether they like it or not.
HostA: And all this right after Tesla’s record profit week? What a contrast in headlines.
HostB: Yeah, tech news is never boring, that’s for sure.
